{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3397510,"name":"","username":"Soren_1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/soren_1/{size}/262420_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-11T03:18:25.680Z","cooked":"

Hello! This year was my freshman year in FRC. The team I joined has one mentor who knows the basics of java and all the seniors of the prior year had essentially made the robot themselves and did not teach any of the other students. This year, there were no seniors, a couple of juniors, and no programmers, so throughout build season, I very poorly hacked together some (barely functioning) code at the same time that I was teaching myself wpilib and java. At the same time, I also had to do building, wiring, machining, and testing because it was essentially me and one other kid who were actually showing up and working (but that’s a story for later).

At our second regional, by sheer luck and no skill, we got to play as backup on the 1st seed alliance in the semifinals (and then broke down halfway through the match). We somehow got a wildcard from that (and our first blue banner), and qualified for worlds. In a stroke of poor freshman thinking I thought it would be a good idea to try to do cool stuff like apriltag localization, auto aiming, auto amp scoring, and note detection instead of focusing on actually important things like good autos, general reliability, and tuning swerve stuff. To be fair, I did (again, poorly) implement these more complex features but when we went to worlds, everything broke. Code kept crashing, auto aiming wasn’t working, odometry and apriltags were all messed up, the pi kept browning out, and our rio 2 just stopped working.

Anyways, getting back on point, I would really appreciate it if I could get some help with learning how to actually code a robot the right way. I have a list of priorities that I want to accomplish before next season or tidal tumble, and I would really like it if someone would be able to give me a hand!
here’s a google doc of the things I would like to learn

Ventura County Regional 2024 - The Blue Alliance","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61769,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Onshape enjoyer"},"post_url":"/t/help-with-programming-please/467487/1","custom_user_title":"Onshape enjoyer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3397580,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-06-11T13:07:26.876Z","cooked":"
Soren_1:

I would really like it if someone would be able to give me a hand!

Ideally, someone with expertise and experience in every aspect of FRC programming would appear, volunteer to be your personal mentor and guide, and work closely and continuously with you as you become a programming master. Chances aren’t good for that to happen, but who knows?

Second best would be to find detailed video or other self-paced training that really walks you through theory and practical implementation of every aspect of FRC programming. I don’t think much exists in this realm. I’ve seen videos on a few topics that get into a little detail, but nothing really on the high end. There are always the WPILib, PhotonVision, etc. docs, which are really quite good, but the depth is limited and these are still in the flavor of documentation rather than training.

What I suggest is that you do a quick CD search on “code release” and prepare to be overwhelmed by the vast amount of on-field proven programming approaches that are at your disposal. For whatever topic you are trying to become better at, match up the code repositories you’ve cataloged with robot capabilities on the field. Sometimes the release post will include highlights of the capabilities that the team felt they executed best. Sometimes just watching a few match videos will reveal particularly effective programming in certain aspects.

If you know nothing about Java and nothing about FRC code structure, looking at code repos is probably not a feasible place to start. However, you’ve already gotten up that first big step, even if it was a trial by fire sort of thing.

One place to start for an example of clean code with some of the features you are looking to implement is the AdvantageKit example code. You might want to start with the regular swerve drive example and then look to the higher frequency odometry “advanced” example further down the road.

Beyond that, just look at other code for specific topics. As just one example, you might want to look at 2910’s code as a way to implement states and state transitions. There are many other repos to be explored with implementations of this or other capabilities you are interested in.

This isn’t a quick solution to your problem, but likely a feasible one and one that will give you some serious depth of knowledge.

One other comment is that this journey is likely to be more fun and more successful if you can find another person to go on it with you. Having someone to discuss things with, get help from, and sustain the energy can make a huge difference.
